awd_titl_txt: 16th US National Congress on Computational Mechanics (USNCCM XVI); Virtual; July 25-29, 2021
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant provides registration support for graduate students and postdoctoral scholars to participate in the 16th US National Congress on Computational Mechanics (USNCCM16) that will be held virtually from July 25 to 29, 2021. USNCCM has been the premier event of the U.S. Association for Computational Mechanics (USACM) since 1991. The biennial event attracts a wide international and US audience covering broad aspects of computational sciences, including topics of fluid mechanics and solid mechanics, mathematics, biology, manufacturing, materials science, nanotechnology, high-performance computing, and data sciences. The conference will be attended by researchers and professionals from industry, governmental laboratories, and academia. Through this grant, the students and post-doctoral researchers will be exposed to the state-of-the-art developments in computational sciences and mechanics. They will also be given opportunities to present their research, attend career events, as well as conduct networking for professional prospects. There will be a special networking event for women researchers in computational mechanics. The organizing committee will make a concerted effort to encourage students and postdocs from underrepresented groups to participate in the overall experience.

At USNCCM XVI, the focus will be on the development and applications of novel, state-of-the-art computational models and numerical methods in a wide variety of scientific and engineering fields. Constitutive behavior, multiphysics phenomena, algorithmic advances, multiscale and data-driven methods, and uncertainty quantification will be covered at substantial length through a wide-ranging program. All talks, including plenary and semi-plenary sessions, will be live streamed. Students and post-doctoral researchers will participate through presentations in technical and special poster sessions. A panel discussion is planned with experts from industry, academia, and government labs to provide future directions and career advice. The Female Researchers Group (FRG) of USACM will also organize a minisymposium for the women researchers on the role and contributions of women in sciences and engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 16th US National Congress on Computational Mechanics was held as a Fully Virtual Event from July 26 to 29, 2021. The conference was widely received by the computational mechanics community with over 1240 conference registrants that represented 36 countries. USNCCM16 also had a record number of student participants (459) and women researchers (181) who took part in the conference.

USNCCM16 offered a strong technical program with 73 minisymposia that were comprised of 269 technical sessions. Over 1075 technical abstracts were presented during the four days of the conference. The Congress featured four Plenary and six Semi-plenary lectures that covered the broad spectrum of Computational Mechanics. Special efforts were made to preserve the in-person flavor of interaction; in particular the general sessions and technical sessions were broadcast live, and GatherTown virtual platform was provided for informal networking opportunities all through the conference.

The other highlights of the conference included a series of mid-day talks celebrating the 30th year of holding USNCCMs. The featured speakers were Professors Bob Taylor, Tinsley Oden, and Tom Hughes who presented reflections and history of USACM. Another highlight was a Symposium Honoring Prof Tinsley Oden's monumental contributions to Computational Mechanics. A Women's Networking Event was organized by the FRG-USACM and FRC-IACM. Another highlight was panel discussion on Navigating the Emerging Landscape of Computational Mechanics, and experts from academia, national laboratories and federal agencies addressed opportunities in the emerging landscape of computational mechanics and shared their thoughts for how to navigate it. Another highlight of the conference was a Panel on the Role of Computational Mechanics in Industry, that discussed the fostering of fruitful mechanics collaborations between academia, national labs, and industry, and the opportunities for students in industrial careers that leverage computational mechanics. A Student Poster Competition was organized with over 30 posters from the participants.

The Conference Organizing Committee acknowledges the National Science Foundation and the Mechanics of Materials and Structures Program for financial support of the conference that made it possible to sponsor over 130 students and post-docs to participate in the congress. Further details on the conference can be reached at http://16.usnccm.org/
